description.info: I finally released my personal website!! After literally months of different revisions, starting from scratch, and all other sorts of procrastinating, I've finally done it!
I'm going to be interning with Qualtrics this Summer at their Provo, UT headquarters. I'll be learning and using cool technologies like GoLang and Caddy to develop for the Fieldsets team.

Litbot is a Slack-bot dedicated to collecting temperature checks (surveys that gauge club direction & mood) and reporting that information in a concise dashboard. I developed the front-end in ReactJS and sort of helped out on serverside routing for the API. If you're curious, check it out here.

Attended TreeHacks @ Stanford University. Worked with two other hackers on PawPrints, a mobile app that sought to gamify and support the lost pet finding process. The app was built with React Native by our two front-end devs and with NodeJS and Google Cloud Store by me.
I joined Code the Change as a front-end developer! CTC helps develop software for social impact organizations in Los Angeles. Learn more about it here.
After working with ACM for a while, I ran for treasurer! And I got it! Now I get to be directly involved in ACM club operation and events. Learn more about ACM @ USC here.

I joined RESL @ USC where I'm currently developing drivers for the open source 'Goby Acoustic Communications' software and the EvoLogics acoustic modem. Ultimately, this software will be used by an autonomous, aquatic drone to gather information about local bodies of water!

description.emphasis: CSCI104 - Data Structures & Object Oriented Programming
description.info: Data Structures was honestly one of my favorite courses at USC, in both content and just overall experience. After scoring pretty well in the class, I decided to apply and become a course producer (undergrad TA).
I joined ACM^2, which is our ACM chapter's equivalent of a 'club internship/training' program! I helped plan and organize events like 'ACM Student Developer Showcase'!
Attended CalHacks @ UC Berkeley. Unfortunately we didn't complete our project, but I had a fun time meeting new people and learning more about hackathon community!
Attended SDHacks @ UCSD. Worked with three other hackers on Vendope, an ios application that sought to match hobbyists and freelancers with local employers.
I joined the Interaction Lab @ USC, where I developed webcam capture and RGB splitting modules in python. These were later used to train machine learning programs.
I started school at USC back in 2015. Fun fact, I actually applied as a Biology major, but this was because I applied before I took AP Computer Science and finally realized how fun the subject was.
